messages: cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:09): I try to load a csv file into a table and have three fields: id, name, secondname
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:09): After a few Minutes oracle 10g web frontend says that a long value can only be inserted in a column of type long.
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:10): The csv file has 250k rows. How should I try to solve my problem?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:10): i would suggest using sqlldr from command line if you are familiar with command lines
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:10): much more flexible
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:10): i am young, willing to learn and good with pcs :>
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:11): sql ldr, hmmm
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:11): tiny command line tool
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:11): it reads a "control file" that describes how data is to be loaded
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:12): Ahh found it.
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:12): Well I guess professionals don't use the web gui anyways :\
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (19:14): my buddy uses sqlldr a lot, the only time I had to load mass amounts of data I used the PL/SQL Developer gui :)
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (19:14): to suck in 25k addresses and related info
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:14): how can I pass table from Oracle into Mysql
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:15): nemo_work: hehe, I try to import musicbrainz db :>
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:15): my data is stored in Oracle, but some tables are required from PHP/MySQL engine
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:15): [algo]: mysql workbench or whatever it is called... mysql provides a nice tool for it
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:16): I need console tool
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:17): that I could call from cron
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:17): select to csv data and load that into mysql
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:18): you could have used the cool copy feature in postgresql if you would have used postgres...
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:18): select to csv with a || ',' || b ?
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:18): hali: if I were a mammoth..
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:18): or the even cooler dbi database links in postgres
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:18): select a||','||b is how it is done
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:18): I don't use postgres
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:18): oracle is better
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:19): for important tasks
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:19): I'm making ETL inserts
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:19): PX Deg Credit send blkd
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:20): is very high wait event
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:23): rr3tzbach: http://rafb.net/paste/results/O7uPzv95.html has an example load
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:24): You are very nice!
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:24): i had an old almost identical example handy
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:24): I got error messages when using: terminated by ","
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:27): 80k rows so far
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:28): And now I'll look into the badfile...
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:28): all about special chars.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:31): [algo]: you could look in to using odbc gateway... but thats a big license cost.. and doesn't have 100% mysql support
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:33): hali:  Oracle Open Gateways ?
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:35): hali: What do I have to do if I only want some fields of the csv file to be imported?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:36): rr3tzbach: use column type filler
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:36): (id, name char, dodo filler, secondname char)
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:37): or certain rows?
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:37): No, columns, thanks again.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:37): use INTO table baho
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:38): Thank you. I am trying to learn a bit about oracle, cause I will move to an department where I'll need it :(
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:38): good for you
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:38): oracle is great fun
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:38): once you learn to taim it :)
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:39): The boss said "freaks always like our department" :>
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:43): Gnar: for option insert the table has to be empty. select * from table says it's empty :\
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:45): truncate it just to make sure?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (19:45): or do append
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:48): I forgot a commit, I am a bloody beginner :\
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (19:49): hali: Thank you for teaching me sqlldr!
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (19:59): I talked to people about that gateway
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (20:00): they say it crashes a lot
e3bece16a9b102049571aab163e47582 (20:00): and has lots of bugs
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:02): i've never used the open/odbc versions
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:02): the sql/400 link worked very well
273d72e2cfe8af3dcc6adc12ddeacefd (20:12): I'm trying to apply logs to an oracle 9i database but it's gotten stuck, asking for logfile arch_1_1.dbf when the last log applied was arch_1_67491.dbf
273d72e2cfe8af3dcc6adc12ddeacefd (20:12): I can't remember how to fix this, anybody else know?
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:16): so, since everyone is active n all.  might as well ask same question from yesterday.
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:16): anyone know an easy way to dump a ref cursor returned from a function in SQL Developer?
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:16): without having to loop through it and do a painful dbms write of each line based on structure.
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:17): some sql to trick it into acting kinda like a select * from foo; would be ideal, so that I just get it parsed n dumped in the editor.
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:17): PL/SQL Developer used to do this automatically, so guess I'm spoiled :-/
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (20:28): Is it daily business to deal with data conversions?
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (20:28): $ sed 's/`t/,/g' track.dat > track2.dat
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:29): that one will break quoted strings
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (20:29): Can you please explain further?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:33): rr3tzbach: you can have a decode statement in your control file if this still is sqlldr related
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:33): or replace(x,y)
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:33): or in 10g .. regexp_replace
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (20:34): I feel dumb now.
ac1daa9b95180e1d1333f4dd644fb85e (20:34): regexp_replace and decode in sqlldr is quite important when konverting from mysql to oracle
cbfe8a2392ad1a7b23d6ee71f0517134 (20:34): fields are separated by \t in my csv file.
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:42): rr3tzbach: picked up on that, I was just noting that if you had "this string has a <tab> in it"<tab>123<tab>
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:42): your sed would break stuff
1ed63740b62505736586b09814ca7ea9 (20:43): rr3tzbach: oh, and by `t you mean \t no? :)
